section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Serving the Guru, devotional worship is practiced.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Then, this human body is obtained.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Even the gods long for this human body.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

text: ਸੋ ਦੇਹੀ ਭਜੁ ਹਰਿ ਕੀ ਸੇਵ ॥੧॥
section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: So vibrate that human body, and think of serving the Lord. ||1||

transliteration.text: sō dēhī bhaj har kī sēv .1.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Vibrate, and meditate on the Lord of the Universe, and never forget Him.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. text: ਮਾਨਸ ਜਨਮ ਕਾ ਏਹੀ ਲਾਹੁ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: This is the blessed opportunity of this human incarnation. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: mānas janam kā ēhī lāh .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. text: ਜਬ ਲਗੁ ਜਰਾ ਰੋਗੁ ਨਹੀ ਆਇਆ ॥
section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: As long as the disease of old age has not come to the body,

transliteration.text: jab lag jarā rōg nahī āiā .

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: and as long as death has not come and seized the body,

transliteration.text: jab lag kāl grasī nahī kāiā .

translation.text: O mortal being, vibrate and meditate on the Lord of the World. ||2||

text: ਅਬ ਨ ਭਜਸਿ ਭਜਸਿ ਕਬ ਭਾਈ ॥

translation.text: If you do not vibrate and meditate on Him now, when will you, O Sibing of Destiny?

translation.text: When the end comes, you will not be able to vibrate and meditate on Him.

translation.text: Whatever you have to do - now is the best time to do it.

translation.text: Otherwise, you shall regret and repent afterwards, and you shall not be carried across to the other side. ||3||

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.
